CENTERED	0001	499	1668	1661	1711	<b><i>BENSONOMYS, CALOMYS, </i>AND THE ORIGIN OF THE </b>
CENTERED	0001	481	1729	1676	1765	<b>PHYLLOTINE GROUP OF NEOTROPICAL CRICETINES </b>
CENTERED	0001	785	1790	1374	1833	<b>(RODENTIA: CRICETIDAE) </b>
CENTERED	0001	938	1902	1222	1942	<b>JON A. BASKIN </b>
CENTERED	0001	442	2006	1746	2040	<b>AssTItAcT.â€” The Late Miocene to Pleistocene North American genus <i>Bensonornys </b></i>
CENTERED	0001	411	2047	1748	2083	<b>is recognized as a subgenus of the Pleistocene and Recent South American genus </b>
CENTERED	0001	410	2088	1749	2125	<b><i>Calornys. </i>Two new species of <i>Calornys </i>are described from the Hemphillian White </b>
CENTERED	0001	410	2129	1746	2163	<b>Cone fauna of Arizona. Characters of this older material indicate that <i>Calomys </i>is </b>
CENTERED	0001	410	2170	1748	2206	<b>derived from <i>Copemys, </i>the cricetine which is also ancestral <i>to Perornyscus. </i>The phyllo-</b>
CENTERED	0001	410	2212	1750	2247	<b>tine group of South American cricetines initially evolved in North America and did not </b>
CENTERED	0001	410	2253	1750	2288	<b>enter South America until the Panamanian land bridge was established, in the latest </b>
CENTERED	0001	411	2296	912	2324	<b>Pliocene or earliest Pleistocene. </b>
CENTERED	0001	368	2399	1820	2438	<b><i>Ehgmodontia arizonae </i>Gidley (1922), from early Blancan deposits of the St. David </b>
CENTERED	0001	336	2444	1818	2483	<b>Formation near Benson, Arizona, was made the type species of the genus <i>Bensonomys </b></i>
CENTERED	0001	336	2490	1823	2530	<b>(Gazin, 1942). Gazin nonetheless noted the many resemblances between the extinct </b>
CENTERED	0001	336	2536	1821	2576	<b>North American genus <i>Bensonomys </i>and the Recent South American phyllotine </b>
CENTERED	0001	332	2580	1821	2621	<b><i>Eligmodontia. </i>Since that time these similarities have been ascribed to parallelism </b>
CENTERED	0001	336	2627	1822	2666	<b>(Hershkovitz, 1966a; Hibbard, 1972). Characters of older material collected from the </b>
CENTERED	0001	337	2673	1821	2711	<b>Bidahochi Formation at White Cone Peak, Arizona, indicate a close relationship </b>as 
CENTERED	0001	336	2719	1822	2759	<b>originally supposed. <i>Bensonomys </i>is herein considered congeneric with <i>Caiomys, </i>an-</b>
CENTERED	0001	336	2764	1822	2803	<b>other South American phyllotine. The two new species of <i>Calomys </i>from White Cone </b>
CENTERED	0001	335	2809	1822	2848	<b>described in this paper are the earliest known members of the Hesperomyini, the </b>
CENTERED	0001	906	2946	1254	2976	<b>GEOLOGIC SETTING </b>
CENTERED	0001	373	3008	1823	3047	<b>White Cone Peak is situated on the joint-use land of the Navajo and Hopi Indian </b>
CENTERED	0001	336	3052	1823	3091	<b>tribes in Navajo County, northeastern Arizona. The White Cone fauna was collected </b>
CENTERED	0001	337	3097	1822	3136	<b>from the upper member of the Bidahochi Formation, approximately 20 m above the </b>
CENTERED	0001	336	3143	1821	3182	<b>volcanic (limburgite tuff) middle member (Repenning et al., 1958). The fauna is </b>
CENTERED	0001	337	3189	1823	3228	<b>characterized by the beaver <i>Dipoides williamsi </i>Stirton (1936) and a mylagaulid </b>
CENTERED	0001	339	3235	1822	3273	<b>(Lance, 1954) and is assigned to the Hemphillian Land Mammal Age. Evernden et al. </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3280	1822	3319	<b>(1964) <i>reported </i>a date of 4.1 million years for the middle member of the Bidahochi </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3326	1822	3362	<b>Formation. The basalt that was used to determine this date, however, was not from the </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3371	1822	3409	<b>middle member, but came from a diatreme within the upper member of the Bidahochi </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3416	1822	3454	<b>Formation. The basalt is unconformable on the upper member where remnants of this </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3461	1823	3500	<b>diatreme are exposed. A basalt which can be traced into the middle member of the </b>
CENTERED	0001	339	3507	1823	3545	<b>Bidahochi Formation at Roberts Mesa, approximately </b>7 <b>mi northwest of White Cone, </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3552	1828	3591	<b>was dated by R. Scarborough of the Department of Geosciences of the University of </b>
CENTERED	0001	339	3597	1825	3635	<b>Arizona at 6.69 ~ 0.20 million years (Scarborough et al., 1974). This date places White </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3642	1823	3681	<b>Cone in the middle Hemphillian. It is no longer the youngest radiometrically dated </b>
CENTERED	0001	338	3779	1824	3818	<b>Cenozoic Epochs (Berggren and Van Couvering, 1974), the Hemphillian is now corre-</b>
CENTERED	0002	339	11	1824	47	<b>lated with the Late Miocene rather than the Middle Pliocene (Wood et al., 1941). The </b>
CENTERED	0002	339	56	1826	95	<b>Late Neogene correlations followed in this paper have <i>not </i>changed the absolute or </b>
CENTERED	0002	1055	175	1106	200	<b>125</b>
CENTERED	0002	671	275	1483	297	<b>This content downloaded from </b>144.92.142.158 <b>on Wed, 8 May </b>2013 <b>16:41:06 PM</b>
CENTERED	0002	975	507	1176	536	<b>MATERIALS</b>
CENTERED	0002	365	570	1817	605	<b>The material described in this paper is the property of the Navajo and Hopi tribes and is </b>
CENTERED	0002	332	611	1823	646	<b>designated by the prefix WC. This material is presently deposited on loan at the University of </b>
CENTERED	0002	331	652	1823	687	<b>Arizona Laboratory of Paleontology (UALP). Except for one illustration of an M' and Ms of </b>
CENTERED	0002	333	694	1818	729	<b><i>Calomys (Bensonomys) meadensis </i>{Hibbard, 1972), only lower dentitions of <i>C. (Bensonomys) </b></i>
CENTERED	0002	332	735	1818	770	<b>have been described. In order to facilitate comparisons with both upper and lower teeth, speci-</b>
CENTERED	0002	331	777	1818	812	<b>mens in the UALP identified by Harrison (1972) as belonging to <i>Bensonomys arizonae </i>from the </b>
CENTERED	0002	333	819	1819	853	<b>Blancan Wolf Ranch local fauna from the St. David Formation were used for this study. Harrison </b>
CENTERED	0002	331	861	1819	895	<b>assigned isolated upper cheek teeth to <i>Bensonomys </i>on the basis of size, crown height, bilobed </b>
CENTERED	0002	331	902	1819	936	<b>anterocone, and very high relative abundance. The following institutions also permitted me to </b>
CENTERED	0002	332	943	1823	977	<b>study specimens of fossil and)or Recent cricetid rodents: Florida State Museum; Museum of </b>
CENTERED	0002	331	984	1818	1019	<b>Comparative Zoology, Harvard University (MCZ); University of Michigan Museum of Paleontol-</b>
CENTERED	0002	364	1067	1819	1101	<b>The dental terminology follows Lindsay (1972). All measurements are in mm. The following </b>
CENTERED	0002	332	1108	1820	1143	<b>values were calculated (Tables 1 and 2): observed range; mean anrl standard error; and coefficient </b>
CENTERED	0002	838	1210	1321	1240	<b>SYSTEMATIC DESCRIPTIONS</b>

FOLLOWED	0002	333	1622	1430	1661	<b><i>(Calomys) </i>has a four-rooted M' and a three- or four-rooted M,.</b>

CENTERED	0002	374	2126	1825	2167	<b><i>Comparisons and discussion.â€” Calomys </i>is distinguished from <i>Eligmodontia </i>and </b>
CENTERED	0002	337	2171	1823	2211	<b>other members of the phyllotine group of neotropical cricetines in having more </b>
CENTERED	0002	336	2217	1823	2258	<b>brachydont cheek teeth and a more bifurcated anterocone(-id). In his specific <i>diag-</b></i>
CENTERED	0002	337	2262	1817	2303	<b><i>nosis, </i>Gidley (1922) compared <i>C. (Bensonomys) arizonae </i>with <i>Eligmodontia morgani </b></i>
CENTERED	0002	338	2308	1822	2350	<b><i>(=E. ty pus). </i>It is <i>not </i>known why Gidley did <i>not </i>make any comparisons with <i>Calomys. </b></i>
CENTERED	0002	337	2353	1828	2395	<b>The synonymy of <i>Calomys </i>is complex (Tate, 1932; Hershkovitz, 1962). For a period of </b>
CENTERED	0002	337	2399	1820	2440	<b>time its species were included in <i>Eli gmodontia. </i>Also, the first specimens <i>of Calomys </b></i>
CENTERED	0002	338	2446	1823	2483	<b>in the National Museum were not collected until 1915 and may have been unavailable </b>

CENTERED	0002	375	2583	1825	2622	<b>Gazin (1942:489) gave the following generic diagnosis for <i>Bensonomys: </i>"Near </b>
CENTERED	0002	335	2629	1825	2668	<b><i>Eligmodontia </i>with knoblike process at anterior extremity of masseteric crest on lower </b>

CENTERED	0003	837	2537	1311	2560	All use subject <b>to JSTOR </b>Terms and Conditions
CENTERED	0003	1021	3206	1079	3231	<b>1mm</b>
CENTERED	0003	374	36	1826	74	<b><i>Of </i>these characters, "more brachydont cheek teeth" and "notch on anterior lobe of </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	81	1821	121	<b>lower cheek tooth better developed" distinguish both <i>Calomys </i>and <i>Bensonomys </i>from </b>
CENTERED	0003	334	127	1822	166	<b><i>Eligmodontia. </i>A deeper lower jaw is characteristic of more primitive species of genera </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	173	1821	211	<b>derived from Copemys (see below) such as <i>Peromyscus valensis </i>(Shotwell, 1967). The </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	218	1823	256	<b>only characteristic of this diagnosis separating <i>Bensonomys </i>from <i>Calomys </i>is lower </b>
CENTERED	0003	375	308	1822	347	<b>Hibbard (1972:92) diagnosed <i>Bensonomys </i>as follows: "About the size of living </b>
CENTERED	0003	334	353	1817	391	<b><i>Eligmodontia typus </i>Cuvier 1837, of South America, which has a four-rooted M,. <i>Ben-</b></i>
CENTERED	0003	335	398	1817	437	<b><i>sonomys </i>has only two roots on the M,. Tooth pattern is more similar to <i>Eligmodontia </b></i>
CENTERED	0003	336	444	1822	482	<b>than <i>Peromyscus, </i>a case of parallel development." This distinction based on root </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	490	1821	528	<b>number is not sufficient, as supernumerary roots are sometimes present on the two </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	535	1820	574	<b>new species of <i>Calomys (Bensonomys) </i>from White Cone and on C. <i>(B.) arizonae. </i>The </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	580	1822	619	<b>dental pattern of fossil <i>Bensonomys </i>is generically indistinguishable from recent </b>
CENTERED	0003	335	625	1818	665	<b><i>Calomys. Bensonomys </i>is retained as a primitive North American subgenus of <i>Calomys </b></i>
CENTERED	0003	337	671	1819	710	<b>in which the consistent presence of supernumerary roots had not been established. Its </b>
CENTERED	0003	372	762	1820	801	<b><i>Calomys (Bensonomys) </i>is distinguished from <i>Peromyscus </i>in having a well-</b>
CENTERED	0003	338	807	1820	846	<b>developed bilobed anterocone(-id) on Mi anterior position of the masseteric crest, </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	853	1820	892	<b>and mental foramen very high on the dentary. It is distinguished from <i>Baiomys </i>in </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	897	1796	936	<b>having relatively wider molars and a well-developed bifurcated anteroconid on M,. </b>
CENTERED	0003	373	943	1822	983	<b><i>Calomys (Bensonomys) </i>is distinguished from Copemys in having alignment or near </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	989	1826	1028	<b>alignment of protolophule II with the anterior arm of the hypocone, and alignment of </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	1033	1826	1073	<b>entolophid with the posterior arm of the protoconid and elongation and bilobation of </b>
CENTERED	0003	337	1079	1821	1119	<b>the anteroconid of M,. Copemys is ancestral to <i>Peromyscus </i>(Clark et al., 1964; Lindsay, </b>
FOLLOWED	0003	340	1124	1637	1162	<b>1972), <i>Onychomys </i>(Hoffmeister, 1959), and <i>other </i>genera of peromyscines. </b>
CENTERED	0003	369	1170	1818	1209	<b><i>Calomys (Bensonomys) </i>has a pronounced reduction in accessory lophs(-ids) and </b>
CENTERED	0003	335	1216	1818	1255	<b>styles(-ids) in comparison to Copemys. Mesolophs and mesostyles occur only in two </b>
CENTERED	0003	335	1261	1819	1300	<b>Hemphillian species, C. <i>yazhi </i>and C. <i>gidleyi. </i>These two also have a very slight </b>
CENTERED	0003	334	1307	1817	1346	<b>nonalignment between protolophule II and the anterior arm of the hypocone. These </b>
CENTERED	0003	334	1352	1818	1391	<b>characters support a Copemys ancestry for <i>Bensonomys. Bensonomys </i>was probably </b>
CENTERED	0003	334	1398	1817	1437	<b>derived from the peromyscine group characterized by small size and a slightly asym-</b>
CENTERED	0003	334	1443	1815	1482	<b>metrical anteroconid that includes <i>Copemys pagei, C. dentalis, </i>and <i>Peromyscus </b></i>
CENTERED	0003	332	1487	1819	1528	<b><i>valensis. Bensonomys </i>differs from these in having a more elongate, consistently bilobed </b>
CENTERED	0003	369	1579	1819	1620	<b><i>Eligmodontia arizonae </i>Gidley (1922) from the Blancan Benson fauna of Arizona </b>

CENTERED	0005	336	3492	1823	3527	with the protoconid; external shelf weakly developed; internal cingulum rudimentary, well-
CENTERED	0005	609	3644	1556	3679	<b>TABLE </b>2.â€” <i>Meastarements of </i>Calomys (Bensonomys) gidleyi.

CENTERED	0007	362	2497	1830	2532	Mst. Subtriangular occlusal outline; three roots, two narrow anterior roots, separate to their base, 
CENTERED	0007	364	2584	1826	2625	<i>Corrsparisons.Calomys (Bensonomys) yazhi </i>is the smallest described species of <i>C. </i>

CENTERED	0007	326	2674	1835	2713	<i>stirtoni </i>in the shorter anteroposterior development of the anteroconid and the offset of 
CENTERED	0007	676	2833	1483	2870	<b>Calomys (Bensonomys) Nidleyi, </b>new species 
CENTERED	0007	907	2894	1250	2932	Table 2; Figs. 1c-d

CENTERED	0007	363	2990	1831	3029	<i>Hypodigrn.â€” WC </i>nos. 190-197, right M', 198 â€” 200, left M'; 201-203, right Ms; 204-

CENTERED	0007	327	3081	1818	3121	220 left M1' 221 â€” 224, right Ms 225 229 left Ms', 230 231 right Ms,' 232 233 left Mg 
CENTERED	0007	327	3126	1827	3165	all from White Cone (UALP locality 6), Bidahochi Formation, northeastern Arizona: 
CENTERED	0007	362	3218	1834	3257	<i>Etymology.â€” Named </i>for J. <i>W. </i>Gidley, who recognized the. neotropical affinities of 
CENTERED	0007	363	3310	1835	3348	<i>Diagnosis.â€” </i>A small brachydont cricetine; M' possesses a mesoloph; anteroconid of 
CENTERED	0007	328	3354	1828	3394	M, is bilobed (internal cusp slightly anterior to external cusp). Calomys <i>gidleyi </i>is 
CENTERED	0007	327	3399	1830	3439	distinguished from <i>C. yazhi </i>by its distinctly <i>larger </i>size, better development of a 
CENTERED	0007	677	3560	1490	3582	This content downloaded from 144.92.142.168 on Wed, 8 May 2013 16:41:06 PM 
CENTERED	0007	847	3584	1320	3607	All use subject to JSTOR Terms and Condition~ 
CENTERED	0008	365	40	1819	75	<i>Description.â€” Teeth </i>low crowned with cusps moderately inflated and slightly alternate; 
CENTERED	0008	365	123	1819	159	M'. Anterocone asymmetrical and bilobed (external cone slightly larger than internal cone); 
CENTERED	0008	333	165	1820	200	mesoloph medium length in four specimens, short in four; small cingular shelf developed an-
CENTERED	0008	332	206	1818	240	terior to the anterocone; internal shelf weakly developed between the protocone and metacone; 
CENTERED	0008	333	246	1818	283	labial cingulum weakly developed between paracone and metacone; weak posterior cingulum; 
CENTERED	0008	334	288	1824	324	slight nonalignment between protolophule II and anterior arm of hypocone; small fourth root 
CENTERED	0008	368	371	1821	408	<b>Ma. </b>Mesoloph rudimentary in four of six specimens; metacone joins hypocone posteriorly; 
CENTERED	0008	371	454	1822	489	<b>Ms. </b>Subtriangular occlusal outline; small hypocone joins metacone (Pl by posterior cingulum. 
CENTERED	0008	370	496	1824	531	M,. Anteroconid relatively wide; cingular shelf moderately developed labially, weakly de-
CENTERED	0008	336	537	1823	572	veloped lingually; valley between anteroconid and metaconid deep; posterior cingulum 
CENTERED	0008	336	579	1822	613	prominent, expanded medially as a small posterostylid and connected lingually with entoconid; 
CENTERED	0008	371	662	1825	697	<b>Ma. </b>Anterior cingulum moderately developed; posterior cingulum well developed and inflated 
CENTERED	0008	370	744	1828	779	Ms. Subtriangular occlusal outline; hypoconid reduced; entoconid absent; posterior arm of 
CENTERED	0008	337	786	1823	821	protoconid directed lingually as a short mesoloph connected with hypoconid by a lingual 
CENTERED	0008	370	894	1822	934	<i>Comparisons.â€” Calomys gidleyi </i>differs from C. <i>yazhi </i>in having a relatively wider 
CENTERED	0008	334	939	1821	978	anteroconid on M,. <i>Calomys gidleyi </i>rarely develops an additional rootlet beneath the 
CENTERED	0008	334	985	1822	1025	paracone on M' as does C. <i>yazhi. </i>However, a minute rootlet occurs occasionally be-
CENTERED	0008	370	1075	1821	1114	<i>Calomys gidleyi </i>differs from C. <i>meadensis, C. arizonae, C. eliasi, </i>and C. <i>stirtoni </i>in 
CENTERED	0008	334	1121	1820	1161	having relatively less elongation and offset of the two cusps of the anteroconid of M,. 
CENTERED	0008	333	1166	1820	1207	<i>Calomys gidleyi </i>is subequal in size to C. <i>meadensis </i>and differs in having a mesoloph, 
CENTERED	0008	333	1213	1822	1252	posterior cingulum, and slight nonalignment of the protolophule II and the posterior 
CENTERED	0008	334	1256	1817	1297	arm of the hypocone of M'. <i>Calomys gidleyi </i>is much smaller than C. <i>arizonae, C. </i>
FOLLOWED	0008	332	1304	718	1342	<i>eliasi, </i>and C. <i>stirtoni.</i>
CENTERED	0008	671	1416	1483	1447	<b>ORIGIN OF THE NEOTROPICAL HESPEROMYINI</b>
CENTERED	0008	371	1477	1819	1516	New World Cricetidae of the subfamily Cricetinae are often placed in three tribes 
CENTERED	0008	335	1522	1821	1561	(Patterson and Pascual, 1972) â€” Neotomini, Peromyscini, and Hesperomyini. The 
CENTERED	0008	336	1567	1821	1607	Neotomini have a complex Ms . They are probably Hemphillian Eurasian immigrants 
CENTERED	0008	333	1612	1820	1653	(Jacobs, 1977). The Peromyscini are the North American group of simple-penis type 
CENTERED	0008	333	1659	1820	1698	cricetines. <i>Copemys, </i>the earliest peromyscine, emigrated from Eurasia to North 
CENTERED	0008	333	1704	1820	1745	America during the Barstovian (Fahlbusch, 1967; Lindsay, 1972). The Hesperomyini 
CENTERED	0008	333	1750	1820	1790	are the dominantly neotropical group of complex-penis type cricetines and are known 
CENTERED	0008	332	1795	1819	1835	from Hemphillian to Recent in North America and from Chapadmalalan (Late Blancan 
CENTERED	0008	370	1886	1820	1926	The origin of the Hesperomyini has been the subject of much debate. Hershkovitz 
CENTERED	0008	334	1932	1819	1973	(1966a, 1969) postulated that the ancestors of the hesperomyines entered South 
CENTERED	0008	332	1977	1818	2018	America from North America in the Early Miocene or earlier and diversified in situ, 
CENTERED	0008	333	2023	1819	2064	with subsequent migration back into Central and North America beginning in the 
CENTERED	0008	334	2068	1819	2110	Blancan. Hershkovitz believed an early colonization was required to explain the high 
CENTERED	0008	333	2111	1820	2155	diversity and specialization of the approximately 40 genera and 180 species of living 
CENTERED	0008	371	2204	1822	2246	In his most recent paper on the origin of the neotropical hesperomyines, Hersh-
CENTERED	0008	331	2251	1818	2291	kovitz (1972) proposed an early Tertiary colonization of South America by African 
CENTERED	0008	331	2298	1818	2336	cricetids. This is virtually impossible. Undoubted cricetid rodents are not known from 
CENTERED	0008	331	2343	1818	2382	anywhere before the Oligocene and do not appear in Africa until the Miocene 
CENTERED	0008	331	2389	1818	2428	(Lavocat, 1973). Africa was separated from Eurasia until the Burdigalian, when the
CENTERED	0008	672	2503	1485	2525	This content downloaded from 144.92442358 on Wed, tt May 2013 16:41:06 PM
CENTERED	0008	841	2527	1315	2550	All use subject to 1STOR Terms and Conditions
CENTERED	0008	334	2724	1827	2762	continents joined and the Cricetodontinae entered Africa (Berggren, 1972; Lavocat, 
CENTERED	0008	372	2813	1828	2852	Hershkovitz favored an African ancestry for the neotropical Hesperomyini because 
CENTERED	0008	334	2858	1832	2897	none of the living Peromyscini have a complex-type penis and because the dentition of 
CENTERED	0008	331	2904	1832	2941	<i>Mystromys, </i>a Pliocene to Recent African cricetid, has a broad resemblance to that of 
CENTERED	0008	334	2949	1828	2988	some phyllotines. This comparison, even if correct, would imply a relatively recent 
CENTERED	0008	333	2994	1826	3032	(Blancan or younger) interchange with Africa. However, Hershkovitz overlooked the 
CENTERED	0008	332	3039	1828	3079	fact that <i>Mystromys </i>has a simplified penis with a undigitate baculum (Hooper and 
CENTERED	0008	333	3086	1826	3124	Musser, 1964; Vorontsov, 1966), an entepicondylar foramen on the humerus (Vor-
CENTERED	0008	332	3131	1826	3169	ontsov, 1966), and the mental foramen low on the dentary. All of these features indicate 
CENTERED	0008	332	3176	1825	3215	that <i>Mystromys </i>is at least as distantly related to the phyllotines as is <i>Peromyscus. </i>
CENTERED	0008	332	3222	1826	3260	Lavocat (1973) included <i>Mystromys </i>within his African section of the Cricetodontinae 
CENTERED	0008	331	3267	1823	3307	because of similarities of the skulls of the Miocene genus <i>Afrocricetodon </i>and <i>Mys-</i>
CENTERED	0008	330	3313	1825	3351	<i>tromys. </i>The dentition of <i>Mystromys </i>is derived from African Miocene cricetodontids 
CENTERED	0008	331	3357	1827	3397	and is similar to that of phyllotines because of convergent adaptation to semi-arid 
CENTERED	0008	332	3404	1825	3442	grassland habitats. Hershkovitz's hypotheses are tenable only if the fossil record is 
CENTERED	0008	369	3495	1826	3533	The fossil record, as presented by Simpson (1950), shows that South America was an 
CENTERED	0008	331	3541	1825	3579	isolated island continent during most of the Tertiary. The only Tertiary mammals 
CENTERED	0008	330	3586	1825	3624	known to have reached South America by waif dispersal before the completion of the 
CENTERED	0008	331	3632	1825	3670	Panamanian land bridge were the caviomorph rodents and the ceboid monkeys in the 
CENTERED	0008	331	3678	1825	3716	Oligocene and procyonids in the Late Miocene. The Cricetidae did not enter South 
CENTERED	0008	330	3723	1825	3761	America until after the land bridge was completed, during the main period of faunal 
CENTERED	0008	331	3769	1827	3807	interchange beginning in the Chapadmalalan (Simpson, 1969). If they had entered
CENTERED	0009	671	1398	1484	1420	Tlus content downloaded Jrom 144.92.142.168 on Wed, tt May 2013 16:41:06 PM
CENTERED	0009	333	1615	1822	1655	of supernumerary roots. A similar condition can also be observed in early <i>Sigmodon. </i>
CENTERED	0009	333	1662	1824	1701	In the Blancan species, S. <i>medius </i>and S. <i>minor, </i>a third root is only rarely present on 
CENTERED	0009	332	1708	1826	1746	the M, (Eshelman, 1975). In the Late Blancan and Irvingtonian S. <i>curtisi, </i>the third root 
CENTERED	0009	333	1753	1821	1792	is well established. Only in later forms are there four roots (Martin, 1974). In Calomys 
CENTERED	0009	330	1799	1824	1838	(Calomys), M, may have three or four roots, Development of supernumerary roots in 
CENTERED	0009	334	1845	1823	1883	different neotropical cricetine lineages is apparently the result of parallelism, perhaps 
CENTERED	0009	333	1890	1822	1929	because of common descent from <i>Copemys. </i>In the subgenus Calomys <i>(Bensonomys) </i>
CENTERED	0009	372	1982	1829	2020	Hershkovitz rejected a North American origin for the Hesperomyini because none of 
CENTERED	0009	334	2027	1824	2065	the living Peromyscini have a complex-type penis. However, possession of a complex-
CENTERED	0009	333	2073	1825	2111	type penis is presumed to have been the primitive condition in the Cricetidae (Hooper 
CENTERED	0009	333	2118	1824	2156	and Musser, 1964). The simple-type penis can be derived from the complex-type by 
CENTERED	0009	334	2164	1825	2202	loss of the lateral digits, and this has occurred independently in many different genera 
CENTERED	0009	333	2209	1823	2246	and species of Cricetidae (Hershkovitz, 1966b). <i>Democricetodon </i>of the Late Miocene 
CENTERED	0009	334	2254	1825	2292	of Europe is synonomous with Copemys of the Late Miocene of North America 
CENTERED	0009	334	2300	1825	2338	(Fahlbusch, 1967). The baculum and penis type of Copemys are as yet unknown but 
CENTERED	0009	333	2345	1829	2383	they are presumed to have been complex because the Old World descendants of 
CENTERED	0009	332	2391	1824	2429	Copemys <i>(=Democricetodon), </i>the Cricetini (Mein and Freudenthal, 1971), have a 
CENTERED	0009	334	2437	1822	2475	complex-type penis. In the New World, simplification occurred in the peromyscine 
CENTERED	0009	334	2482	1823	2520	radiation from Copemys. The complex penis was retained in the hesperomyine radia-
CENTERED	0009	333	2527	1823	2565	tion. Diversification of the Hesperomyini had begun in North America at least seven 
CENTERED	0009	334	2573	1819	2611	million years ago, long before the completion of the Panamanian land bridge. <i>Ben-</i>
CENTERED	0009	332	2618	1824	2657	<i>sonomys </i>represents a part of that radiation that was taking place in the southern portion 
CENTERED	0009	333	2664	1821	2702	of North America much as Patterson and Pascual suggested. Further peripheral records 
CENTERED	0009	333	2709	1822	2748	of this evolution are the Early Blancan appearance of a sigmodont, <i>Sigmodon medius, </i>
CENTERED	0009	333	2755	1827	2793	and a possible akodont, <i>Symmetrodontomys simplicidens, </i>of the Rexroad fauna of 
CENTERED	0009	333	2800	1822	2838	Kansas before they are known from South America. With the completion of the 
CENTERED	0009	334	2845	1823	2883	Panamanian land bridge, members of this initial radiation entered South America 
CENTERED	0009	370	2936	1822	2975	There is no reason to hypothesize that this hesperomyine radiation began prior to 
CENTERED	0009	333	2981	1823	3021	about 10 million years ago. The hesperomyine tooth pattern cannot be directly derived 
CENTERED	0009	333	3027	1822	3067	from any cricetid rodent known prior to the Late Clarendonian. Copemys and the 
CENTERED	0009	333	3072	1821	3111	aberrant and poorly known <i>Gnomomys </i>are the only two genera of cricetines known 
CENTERED	0009	333	3117	1821	3157	from the Barstovian and Clarendonian of North America (Lindsay, 1972). During the 
CENTERED	0009	334	3163	1822	3203	Clarendonian, the dental pattern of Copemys began to simplify, losing accessory 
CENTERED	0009	334	3209	1822	3248	lophs(-ids) and styles(-ids) (Lindsay, 1972). During the Hemphillian, alignment of the 
CENTERED	0009	333	3255	1822	3294	protoconid-entoconid and paracone-hypocone was achieved to form the peromyscine 
CENTERED	0009	372	3347	1822	3386	Black (1963) reported the possible presence of much earlier (Hemingfordian) hes-
CENTERED	0009	333	3392	1822	3429	peromyine cricetines from the Thomas Farm fauna of Florida. He noted the re-
CENTERED	0009	335	3437	1822	3477	semblances of an upper molar fragment to <i>Sigmodon </i>and of an Ml to a peromys-
CENTERED	0009	333	3481	1822	3522	cine or hesperomyine. These teeth are from Pleistocene deposits containing 
CENTERED	0009	332	3528	1820	3568	<i>Platygonus </i>which also occur at Thomas Farm. The M, belongs to <i>Peromyscus flori-</i>
CENTERED	0009	332	3573	1823	3613	<i>danus. </i>The upper molar fragment belongs to a small, relatively high crowned 
CENTERED	0009	333	3618	1823	3657	<i>Sigmodon, </i>perhaps S. <i>bakeri. </i>Other lophate supposedly cricetine teeth of the 
CENTERED	0009	335	3665	1821	3704	Oligocene and Miocene have proven to be deciduous teeth of geomyoids (Black, 1969). 
CENTERED	0009	334	3710	1822	3749	The tendency towards simple lophate teeth in cricetines did not begin until the Late 
CENTERED	0009	331	12	1825	50	earlier they would probably have been found as fossils in earlier deposits as have the 
CENTERED	0009	369	102	1825	140	Patterson and Pascual (1972) supported and elaborated Simpson's arguments, pos-
CENTERED	0009	331	146	1826	186	tulating a tropical North American center of cricetine diversification in the Clarendo-
CENTERED	0009	331	192	1826	231	nian and Hemphillian, with Chapadmalalan immigration of an already diversified 
CENTERED	0009	331	238	1826	276	cricetine fauna into South America. Hershkovitz (1966a, 1969, 1972) misinterpreted 
CENTERED	0009	331	284	1826	323	this and attributed to them just a single Central American species emigrating to South 
CENTERED	0009	330	329	1830	369	America. Although vertebrate paleontologists have been unable to cite positive proof 
CENTERED	0009	330	375	1824	414	for their hypothesis, the absence of such evidence does not indicate that this theory is 
CENTERED	0009	332	421	1826	460	wrong. Late Tertiary fossiliferous terrestrial deposits in tropical North America are 
CENTERED	0009	331	466	1825	506	very limited. To date they have produced no small mammals (Ferrusquia-Villafranca, 
CENTERED	0009	334	512	1826	551	1975), but the large mammals wholly corroborated Simpson's history of faunal inter-
CENTERED	0009	331	557	1825	596	change. White Cone is one of the southernmost known North American Hemphillian 
CENTERED	0009	331	602	1826	641	rodent faunas and provides the first peripheral records of what may be a Central 
CENTERED	0009	331	648	1825	687	American Hemphillian cricetine radiation (see also Jacobs, 1977). The close relation-
CENTERED	0009	332	692	1826	732	ship of Hemphillian and Blancan species of Calomys <i>(Bensonomys) </i>in North America 
CENTERED	0009	331	738	1826	778	to Chapadmalalan and younger species of Calomys (Calomys) in South America pro-
CENTERED	0009	330	782	1825	823	vides positive evidence in support of Simpson's as well as Patterson and Pascual's 
CENTERED	0009	369	874	1824	915	The presence of supernumerary roots on the White Cone Calomys <i>(Bensonomys) </i>
CENTERED	0009	332	919	1826	959	removes Hibbard's (1972) objection to <i>Bensonomys </i>having a close relationship with 
CENTERED	0009	333	967	1827	1005	neotropical cricetines. Peromyscine teeth typically have three upper and two lower 
CENTERED	0009	333	1013	1829	1050	roots. Hesperomyini can have four upper and three or four lower roots on their 
CENTERED	0009	333	1058	1826	1096	cheek teeth. Supernumerary roots are not known in Copemys. Calomys <i>yazhi </i>has 
CENTERED	0009	331	1103	1821	1142	a four-rooted M'. A fourth root is occasionally present on M' of C. gidleyi and of C, 
CENTERED	0009	329	1149	1826	1188	<i>arizonae </i>from the early Blancan Wolf Ranch fauna. Calomys <i>gidleyi </i>may develop a 
CENTERED	0009	331	1195	1821	1233	three-rooted M,. M~ and M3 of C. <i>yazhi </i>are three rooted. Extra roots when present in C. 
CENTERED	0009	328	1241	1824	1279	<i>(Bensonomys) </i>are similar to those present in Calomys <i>callosus </i>or <i>Sigmodon hispidus. </i>
CENTERED	0009	369	1286	1826	1323	It is not unexpected that the earliest species of Calomys have variable development
CENTERED	0010	369	11	1820	51	Parallelism has often been invoked to explain similarities between groups of ro-
CENTERED	0010	332	57	1826	98	dents. However, when details of similarity far outweigh differences, the hypothesis of 
CENTERED	0010	331	101	1820	142	parallelism must be discarded and the hypothesis of a close phylogenetic relationship 
CENTERED	0010	330	146	1820	188	must be adopted. This is especially true when intermediate morphological stages are 
CENTERED	0010	670	308	1482	330	This content downloaded from 144.922423 58 on Wed, 8 May 2013 16:41:06 PM
CENTERED	0010	839	332	1313	355	Att use subject to JSTOR Terms and Conditions
CENTERED	0010	372	532	1820	571	Wilson (1937161) stated in his discussion of Catomys (Bensonomys) <i>arizonaei </i>
CENTERED	0010	334	577	1822	616	<i>"Eligmodontia... </i>is sufficiently close to <i>Peromyscus </i>to have been derived from this 
CENTERED	0010	334	623	1823	662	form or its immediate predecessors before migration to South America, but what actu-
CENTERED	0010	333	669	1822	708	ally occurred is not known." The further fossil evidence presented in this paper shows 
CENTERED	0010	334	714	1822	753	that the primitive phyllotine Calomys <i>(BensonomlIs) </i>evolved in North America from 
CENTERED	0010	331	760	1824	798	<i>Perompscus' </i>immediate predecessor Copemys during the Hemphillian, followed by 
CENTERED	0010	333	805	1823	843	migration of Calomys to South America in the Chapadmalalan. This documents in 
CENTERED	0010	333	851	1823	889	more detail the phylogeny that Wilson (1937) had suspected several decades ago, and 
CENTERED	0010	332	896	1822	934	the history of faunal differentiation and interchange that Simpson (1950) first pro-
CENTERED	0010	894	1032	1260	1061	<b>ACKNOWLEDGMENTS </b>

FOLLOWED	0015	106	1830	2100	1932	<i>liscomys, Chelemyscus, Chinchillula, Phyl </i>
FOLLOWED	0015	106	1942	2136	2042	<i>lotis, Paralomys, Graomys, Eligmodontia, </i>
FOLLOWED	0015	108	2052	2134	2154	and <i>Hesperomys. </i>Amer. Mus. Novitates, 
FOLLOWED	0015	102	2502	2134	2600	<i>Mystromys </i>Wagn. (Mammalia, Glires). Zool. 
CENTERED	0015	372	3675	1825	3711	<i>Florida State Museum and Department of Zoology, University of Florida, Gainesville, </i>
